verses.verse: (The Humiliation of Babylon) (Jer 46.11; 48.18; 51.33) Come down and sit in the dust, virgin daughter Babylon! Sit on the ground without a throne, daughter Chaldea! For you shall no more be called tender and delicate.
Take the millstones and grind meal; remove your veil; strip off your robe; uncover your legs; pass through the rivers.
(Isa 34.8; 63.4; Ezek 16.37) Your nakedness shall be uncovered, and your shame shall be seen. I will take vengeance, and I will spare no one. (Meaning of Heb uncertain)
(Isa 41.14) Our Redeemer—the LORD of hosts is his name— is the Holy One of Israel.
(v 7|ISA 47:7; Isa 13.10, 19; 23.2; Dan 2.37) Sit in silence, and go into darkness, daughter Chaldea! For you shall no more be called the mistress of kingdoms.
(Deut 28.50; Isa 10.13; 43.28; Zech 1.15) I was angry with my people; I profaned my heritage; I gave them into your hand; you showed them no mercy; on the aged you made your yoke exceedingly heavy.
(v 5|ISA 47:5; Isa 42.25; 45.21) You said, “I shall be mistress forever,” so that you did not lay these things to heart or remember their end.

(Isa 32.9, 11; Zeph 2.15; Rev 18.7) Now therefore hear this, you lover of pleasures, who sit securely, who say in your heart, “I am, and there is no one besides me; I shall not sit as a widow or know the loss of children”—

(Isa 13.16, 18; Nah 3.4; 1 Thess 5.3) both these things shall come upon you in a moment, in one day: the loss of children and widowhood shall come upon you in full measure, in spite of your many sorceries and the great power of your enchantments.

(v 8|ISA 47:8; Ps 52.7; Isa 29.15; 44.20) You felt secure in your wickedness; you said, “No one sees me.” Your wisdom and your knowledge led you astray, and you said in your heart, “I am, and there is no one besides me.”

(v 9|ISA 47:9; Isa 57.1; 1 Thess 5.3) But evil shall come upon you, which you cannot charm away; disaster shall fall upon you, which you will not be able to ward off, and ruin shall come on you suddenly, of which you know nothing.
(v 9) Stand fast in your enchantments and your many sorceries, with which you have labored from your youth; perhaps you may be able to succeed; perhaps you may inspire terror.

(Isa 57.10; Dan 2.2) You are wearied with your many consultations; let those who study (Meaning of Heb uncertain) the heavens stand up and save you, those who gaze at the stars and at each new moon predict what (Gk Syr Compare Vg: Heb from what) shall befall you.
(Nah 1.10; Mal 4.1) See, they are like stubble; the fire consumes them; they cannot deliver themselves from the power of the flame. No coal for warming oneself is this, no fire to sit before!
(Isa 43.13; 46.7; Rev 18.11) Such to you are those with whom you have labored, who have trafficked with you from your youth; they all wander about in their own paths; there is no one to save you.
